column11: Review Text

A real insider tip when you are in Kandy: this temple and those of Lankathilaka and Embekka are called the "3 temple loop" and can be easily driven together. There are hardly any tourists here, and GAdeladheniya seems almost enchanted.

column8: "Tranquility and History at Its Best â€“ A Must-Visit for Couples"
column11: Our visit to the Temple of Gadaladeniya was nothing short of magical. Tucked away in a peaceful corner of Kandy, this historic temple provided a serene escape from the hustle and bustle of daily life.

column8: The brick temple (and Mr Rathnajake): third stage of the trek of the three temples.
column11: Third and last stop of our trek of the three temples, the granite and brick temple of Gadaladeniya, also from the mid-1300s, built in a South Indian style on a less high black rock but similar to Lakathilake, with the access steps cut into the rock itself, with a long inscription. In the hall of the shrine there is an original statue of a Buddha sitting in meditation. At the entrance, however, there are also Hindu deities. There is then a secondary shrine consisting of a covered stupa with a roof and four other small stupas on the sides, where 4 Buddha statues are housed. We found it full of schoolchildren and were greeted by the caretaker-artist, Mr Rathnajake. He will tell you the story of the temple and much more with the love he employs in his designs. We bought them with great satisfaction :-). The temple is located near the bus stop to Kandy.

column8: One of the 3 Temples Visited Outside of Kandy
column11: It was long tuktuk drive from one  Ambakka Temple to this one, passing by village roads, such of which have pot holes. Entrance fee is 500 LHR. Took off my shoes in the area where entrance fee was paid. The barefoot walk from the Payement Office was on hot, black rocks. Exhibits noted are mostly statues of Buddhas in various conditions and positions. Someone was drumming as I walked from one building to another. Note that there is also a huge Stupa here.

column8: Experience of a magnificient historical site
column11: Temple of the Gadaladenia locates around 10 km away from Kandy city. It is a place in Sri Lanka with rich tradition. Temple was built nearly 700 years ago at the time of Polonnaruwa Kingdom. Gadaladeniya ancient temple contains Hinduism influence but with Sinhalese architecture and it was built under patronage of King Bhuvanekabahu V.
This temple is located near to kandy. It is beautiful temple. It is buddhist temple. The stone carvings here are very unique.

On our visit plan near Kandy , we decided to visit this temple me and my two Sri Lankan friends . They got stopped asked to pay entrance fee since I was foreigner , nothing unique in Sri Lanka but really unusual for a place dedicated to spirituality. I cannot imagine having foreigner asked to pay to enter a church back home in France . The worse think was the aggressive attitude of one of the monk which was verbally insulting my friends , both of my friends are Buddhist and were really disgusted by the whole situation. Small message for the monk business oriented be more kind and both local and foreigner will be more than happy to donate money for your temple , like itâ€™s done everywhere else.

This temple was built in 14th century with Hinduism influence with Sinhalese architecture from Polonnaruwa era and Indochina architectural style, under patronage of King Bhuvanekabahu V. Some interesting facts about this temple is that it was built on top of the rock outcrop; there are interesting sculptures with figures of elephant head with lion body; and a few nice lily ponds. Many scaffoldingâ€™s are the temple for restoration works. Worth a short visit of 30 mins visit with entrance fee of LKR300 per person.

column8: Galdaladeniya temple is sri lanka is an old monastery build over a rock in district of kandy.j
column11: According to an inscription carved into wall the temple was built in1344 AD by king Buwanakabahu the forth.the temple was desing by the south indian architect.

column8: A 14th century Buddhist temple strongly influenced by Hindu architecture
column11: This is not one of the big sites for either local or foreign tourists, but is worth going to.  It is a one hour visit and you can take cameras and walk in shoes except when entering the temple itself.
Must of course take shoes off to enter and on a hot day like when we visited, be aware the ground is so very hot on the bare feet.

Not much to see - it is a little rock temple, famous for its age and some drawing you can see inside. The men in charge there (who is also the guide) is nice and he spend his time re-drawing the drawings you can see on the doors there :). He is very knowledgeable about the history of the temple, so you can ask him anything if you are interested.
This is a very old Temple located close to Kandy Area. Drawings in the temple are very valuable. Anyone who visits there doesn't forget to have a look on the Drawings.
Another smaller temple for the Hindu. Just pass by and view the white and black architecture - not a huge one.

A 14th century ancient Buddhist temple with Sinhalese and Hindu unique architectural mix. Once abandoned, the temple is locate 12 km away from city centre on top of a rock with lush green view of paddy fields and villages. The place is basically for historians who love explore different cultures. Area is renowned for brass work.
this temple built in gompola era nearly 600 years a go.still standing well this stricture and uncommon stupa as well.

The nice, little Buddhist temple is considered one of the largest rock temples of the country and dates back to the 14th century, being built in 1344, during the reign of King Bhuvanekabahu IV. It is one of the three "temples of the loop", there's hardy any tourist there and very much worth a short visit...
This is an ancient Buddhist and Hindu temple here. A very good temple to visit and spend couple of hours here.
Another amazing temple but this has suffered with rain damage - I hope the Sri Lankan government will come to the rescue. Again, locals and the resident monk happy to give information.

Gadaladeniya Viharaya in Kandy Built almost exclusively of stone in 1344 by the Gampola King Wicramabahu, is situated on a hilltop, commanding views of the surrounding countryside. The architecture is Dravidian. The entrance porch features large stone pillars, which support a roof of huge stone slabs. Temple is well maintained and there is a small donation to be made when you visit.
Go there only if You are religiously interested. Notjing much to see. No information / display. Still you have to pay
Built on an outcrop of rock with lotus pools and several shrines, it was quite atmospheric and well worth the half day trip out from Kandy.
Unfortunately this temple was under renovation during my visit so i did not even bother going in as it was a hot day. Probably worth a visit when the work is completed.

It's 1km from the a1 road from colombo to Kandy. Turn from the pilimatalawa junction. One of the three famous temples on this road. Nothing much to see. Not a must visit, but if you have time to kill why not?

This ancient rock Temple was the first, and my favourite of the three Temple loop. Builit on an outcrop of rock with lotus pools and several shrines, it was quite atmospheric and  well worth the half day trip out from Kandy.
An old temple dating from the 1300s Situated in a nice location in a small village It is possible to walk the three temples circuit from here about six Km in total. You will need a guide to do this

really beautiful temple build up on a rock which gives secondary this feeling and look. you find diverse statue and two buildings. the guide in the temple paint as well by himself and is very friendly to answer questions about the history.
Lovely temple with beautiful internals. However my guide was a bit upset that some of the site had not been tidied
Nice view over the city. Not overcrowded. Really nice temple inside the Buddha which looks over the city.

Not crowded at all. This place gives you the facility to go through the great Kandyan era culture and also the wood cravings It has a history for around 400 years and less touristic place in Kandy. The area near this Temple is popular for traditional brassware practised for many generations
Best place to visit while you are in Kandy with surrounding other two temples Embekke devalaya and Lankathilaka viharaya.
Beautiful setting on a rock with lotus pools. The resident artist/archaeologist gave us some information and sold us a postcard.

Gadaladeniya temple basking on the city of kandy is a well-known tourist destination in Sri lanka. Usually, it is visited by devotees, pilgrims, History enthusiasts and nature lovers. The temple of Gadaladeniya plays a key role in Sri lankan tourism.
We were almost alone at the temple which gave a unique experience. The guy selling tickets also sels these amazing coloured drawings - We bought 3ðŸ˜Š

A temple build in Gampola (after Kandyan) era. Paintings in the entrance is preserved. There is an artist/ tour guide in the place. He explains very well and there are paintings/ Post cards to buy. Better to take extra socks as the ground gets very hot during day time and you have to remove the shoes before entering the temple premises. Tickets are priced 300 LKR for foreigners.
Very beautiful and small "vihara" to be visited with Embekke and Lankatilaka. It's worth the visit to see the afrescos in the small dagobas around the big dagga

Located in a small hill top. Can reach by a car. 13Km from Kandy. Mix of a Sinhala(Majority) and Hindu Culture. Built by king Wickramabahu. ideal place If interested in Buddhism and culture. Should wear trouser and long sleeve top.

Having seen so many temples this was a change from the norm and we felt it was largely undiscovered by tourists but visited frequently by locals. Its currently being done up and has scaffolding up but is still very impressive, in a really small way, the paintings inside are simply amazing. Not only that but the 2 or 3 out buildings are really interesting as well, again the painting are great. A most interesting place and one we would happily go back if given a chance. So good and fun to have the interaction with the children outside.

The name Gadaladeniya has been derived from meaning bed of rock, and is one of the ancient Buddhist temples in Sri Lanka. The temple has been built in the 14th Century, during the time where King Buvenakabahi IV was ruling the country, with the guidance of Ven. Seelawamsa Dhammakeerthi. The temple has been designed by South Indian architect  Ganesvarachari. The design of the temple depicts a mix of Sri Lankan to Indo Chinese architecture. Been here couple of times, and what impresses me the most is the fine rock carving that can be see.

When i travel to different countries I make sure I visit the local worship temples.This was anexcellent few hours and would recommend it. Bare in mind men have to cover knees and ladies their shoulders as respect.

The Gadaladeniya Raja temple is small, on a dead end street in a neighborhood of brass manufacture, and next to a trash area that collects recycled soda cans. It is not visible from the street. All you can see is sheer rock â€“ the temple is actually situated on a huge rock. Stone steps have been carved into the rock as well as a long message. It was built in 1344. There is a main temple with a huge Buddha statue, much more expressive than modern ones. I had a real sense of prayer and holiness when I went in. I think it is because this is actually a neighborhood temple. There is a constant stream of local people in prayer. The temple also has a stupa built on sheer rock with four side chapels with images. There is renovation going on. I cannot believe that one of the reviewers said that there is nothing much to see! The image of the Lord Buddha is amazing.

This temple and stupa are situated on a rocky outcrop; although quite easy to wander about as it's not that steep. Only the rear entrance was open but it still allowed a view of the fading Lion paintings on the entrance walls, before being dazzled by the large gold painted meditating Buddha statue between two gold painted statues resting on adjacent walls. Note the various heads above the statues plus the decorated walls. Worth a visit.
its sad to see that the temple was neglected. no body is there to guide or look after such historically valuable temple.

This was under construction at the time we went. So, better to check whether the constructions have been finished, before going. The place was pretty much similar to Lankatilaka temple. Booklets about the temple was available to buy. Parking was available near the temple for free. But it was not a proper parking.

column7: Emirate of Sharjah, United Arab Emirates
column11: Gadaladeniya is an old monastery in Sri Lanka it was built on a rock and it contains very beautiful paintings.

Gadaladeniya, Lankatilaka and Embekke Devale Temples comprise the Three-Temples Loop about half hour's drive from Kandy. With transport (car or tuk-tuk) they can all be visited together in ~ 2 hours and are not particularly busy. This temple, Gadaladeniya, is built on a rock and is very interesting and pretty to visit.
Located around 13kilometers away from the kandy town. Beautiful drawings and amazing architecture . If you have enough time in kandy worth visiting this place.

We went to this temple twice, once in the day just to take some photos of the outside. Didn't stick around long so we didn't pay to go in, but that is an option if you have time. The real beauty of this place was at night, we saw a ceremony that our tuk tuk driver took us to. We were the only tourists around and got to see a stunning celebration - and no fee at night! There were many different types of traditional Kandy culture dancers, fire dancers and 4 elephants all dressed up with costumes and lights. It actually ended up being a ceremony with another temple as well so there were more dancers and 4 more elephants from another temple! Absolutely gorgeous. Our tuk tuk driver told us this doesn't happen that often, so you can always check to see if it's going on when you visit. He also told us that the same elephants will do the festivals at the Temple of the Tooth, so you could see this there too. An amazing experience- definitely glad we went!

We organised a tuk tuk tour of the temples around Kandy and the war cemetery which took half a day and cost 2000LR including tip - well worth doing rather than paying for an expensive organised tour. The curator at the temple spoke excellent english, explained all about it's history and was produsing some lovely art work. Although the temple is undergoing restoration, it is well worth the trip - you can enter the shrine and see the casket where Buddha's tooth was originally held.

An amazing historical site,which is of great interest. Try to go early morning when it is not to hot and the sightseers are not as many. We found lots of things to photograph and our guide was very helpful in explaining everything to us,take plenty of fluids as not many places to buy things. A truly great place.
If you are travelling along Kandy Colombo main road it is only 1km away from Pilimathalawa town.. only few km away from Lankathilaka & Embakke devala. Situated top of a rock. Famous place for locals.
Although the entrance fee was modest, it was only when we approached the temple we were informed it was 'closed during roof repairs' so we paid to see very little at all!

This a very ancient temple located close by to Kandy. It has its historical statues, buildings as it is. If you are visiting kandy this is a place you must visit. There is a good view of the environment. When you come to the summit of the temple you can see Far Nelligala Temple, Ranawana Temple statue etc.
Designed by a south Indian architect this temple is an amazing structure located very close to Kandy.

The chief architect of this temple south Indian nationalist called Ganaesvarachari as this temple is related to south Indian design their original painting still exhibit on 638 year old jack wood doors. Also Gadaladeniya temple image room has had damage by the Portuguese

I went to Gadaladeniya temple by motor bike ride. It's 15km from Peradeniya junction. We tracked the root by Google map and reached there around 30mins. The temple is maintained as it's unique style and calm place to stay.
calm tranquil spiritual peaceful real contentment  without too much hustle and bustle.Worth the visit

We spent one day discovering the three temples 30km from the kandy city centre. Our tuktuk-driver (Samera, tel 0094776337225) drove us safely to all three of them and showed us the botanical garden and a spice garden. He showed us everything. Would recommend him very much. The temples are quiet but very nice. No people and you could realy enjoy the calm and quiet athmosphere. Samera also helped us organising a 5 day trip with a car from Kandy to see all the historic sites around Anuradapura, Polonaruwa, Sigirya, Dambulla and Adam's Peak.
Be sure to watch your footing here,  Irregular steps and a little dark on the inside, but so worth every inconvenience!  Bring a little offering, say a prayer and be gladdened!

We visited here first as part of the three temples loop, and were fortunate to be shown around by an artist who explained huge amounts about Buddhist symbolism and imagery. The temple is ancient and captivating, and definitely shouldn't be missed.

This temple is part of the "Three Temple Loop" near Kandy - a historic and interesting site.   We enjoyed seeing a group of local school children having their religious instruction class there - it is good to see this historic site still in daily use by the locals!

This is a relatively modest place, in contrast to the magnificent Temple of the Tooth, but with great atmosphere - a combined Buddhist and Hindu place of worship. We arrived during an offerings ceremony at the Buddhist temple.  A local guide then talked us through the fascinating 14th Century wood carvings and their religious significance before we were invited into the temple inner sanctum by the resident monk to see the wonderful and colourful seated Buddha and surrounding artwork - apparently a special privilege for us. As we recovered our shoes we were engaged by a local woodcarver and, after the obligatory good-humoured bargaining, bought a small souvenir to help support the local economy. As always in Sri Lanka, the people were friendly and keen to talk.

As most of the temples in Sri Lanka, you have to take your shoes off when visiting this temple, I advice you bring socks with you, because the big rocks on temple floor get hot all day it's hard to walk barefoot. There is also a tiny water lilies pond formation between the rocks on the garden.
I've been here recently. well true that its a historical place. But the place is poorly maintained and nothing much to see. Don't advice anyone to go there just for this place.
One of the living testimony of ancient Sri Lankan arts and craft ability and they are all well preserved all those long gone years stands even to day with great pride

Though being constructed in 1344, just as Lankatilake was, this temple has a far more south Indian flare (having been designed by a Tamil architect) with one of the most unusual temples to be found on the island thanks to its dagoba.  There are are some fine faded paintings in the area along with some nice sculptures and a large Buddha statue whose eyes are oddly closely set together. At time of writing though the roof of the corbelled roof of the main shrine was under repairs so the scaffolding was not ideal for photos admittedly. Otherwise, this fine temple is open from 8-18h, but expect to pay 300 rupees for entrance to a kindly groundskeeper who also sells watercolours he paints while minding the door.

This is a famous temple among the locals as it was built by the Kandyan Kings. Since I am a Sri lankan, I have nothing much to see other than a typical old temple. But one may be interested in the building architecture.
This is the first, some 2km from Pilimathalawa: the bus stand is just in front of the temple. The entry fee is 150 rupees. Just open your guidebook, and visit peacefully.
Only informative if you have a guide, so definitely recommend finding one when you arrive outside.  Take a walk all the way around...you'll enjoy it.
A very cool temple with a lot of history.  Our guide was great in delivering the information in a meaningful way.  Not busy at all. Check it out!

One of the most suggested half-day tours in Kandy is to the "three temples" that like about 15km away. The journey by tuk-tuk is lovely (and you can stop by the Botanic gardens along the way). Each of the temples is fascinating in its own way. These are not really tourist attractions but places of worship and you are more likely to see Buddhists here than pallid Europeans wielding cameras (that would be me). What is intriguing in the Buddhist temples of Sri Lanka is the extent to which Buddhism subsumes Hinduism - most of these temples have shrines to Vishnu, and the temple carvings and architecture had more in common with the Hindu temples of Java than with the stupas of south east Asia.

We went on a tour of the three main temples outside of Kandy. This temple is located less the 2km from the Colombo-Kandy road. It is built on a rocky outcrop, with numerous small rock pools. You will need to pay an entrance fee Rs300 per person and the ticket seller also does hand painted postcards of the temple, which he will try and sell. The complex consists of a white stupa, with four small shrines on each of the cardinal points. The temple itself was covered in scaffolding, to protect it from the rain, which apparently has been in place for a number of years. Inside is a large seated Buddha. It's a pleasant place to visit but I wouldn't make a specific trip just to see this temple complex.

I did'n have it in my list but passed on the way to airport. It is on top of the large rock. Very nice and quiet place. A painter was painting in paper. Some grandmas were chanting. The temple architects in stone. Very historical.
Another must visit when holidaying in Sri_lanka. You'll need about 3 to 4 hrs to take it all in. Be respectful when entering as its quite a revered place. You are allowed to take pictures too!Enjoy.
the temple of Gadaladeniya is on best location to visit  those like to know the last part of the Sri lanka  history.Its have big architectural value.

We passed the temple on our way to Kandy. It was a very nice experience to see some of the oldest statues and paintings on the walls. Huge Buddha statue made from gold. Fortunately we were there with a local friend who told us the story behind this temple.

Old place, holy shrine, however not well maintained. We were asked to pay Rs 300 entry fees per person so we decided not to get in. Saw a little bit of the complex. Was well visited by the locals. It was raining a bit so didn't stay there for long. Appeared quiet and peaceful.

We visited this on a tour of the three temples outside of Kandy recommended in many guidebooks. If you have time to spend in Kandy, it is worth the visit, but I wouldn't spend more time in Kandy just to see it. The old frescoes here were quite nice. We hired a three-wheeler to take us to all three sites for about 2000 rupees.
This temple is situated a few meters away from the Colombo-Kandy main road.  This shows us the creativity of old day people
Nice place to see some beautiful paintings as well as carvings. Best to combine with a visit to Lankatlaka temple. Peaceful.

To reach Gadaladeniya temple you need to turn off Kandy road at Pilimathalawa and drive four kilometres. This temple was constructed in the year 1636 according to the writing's on stone on the temple grounds. The pagoda at this temple bears unique design. The usual pagoda  has 4 buddha statues placed within small shrine rooms around the stupa . But here the shrine rooms are constructed with stone and is the Base of the stupa. Also the main shrine room shows the architecture of the period including an impressive huge wooden door with a stone frame.

Don't miss to visit this place if you are in Kandy.Gadaladeniya is one of the best place to view the original stone carving designs.There are many carvings on the pillars & you will be amazed by the beauty of this temple.

Any one who likes to visit temple of the Gadaladeniya there is one person issue entrance tickets He may ask from you (can I explain the temple for you) donâ€™t miss this chance. Say yes he will explain you this temple perfectly

Though this temple is known as "Gadaladeniya" today, An inscription identifies this temple as "Dharma Kirthi Viharaya" which is the name of the founding monk. The work "Nikaya Sangrahaya" identifies this temple as "Saddharmathilake" and "Saddharmalankaraya" identifies this as "Gadaladeniya Viharaya" after the village which it is located.

The temple's unique design and architecture has inspired many including Geoffrey Bawa. I really enjoyed my visit here. The temple is under some renovation (June 2015). You would see many temples around Sri Lanka that have been inspired by Gadaladeniya's architecture. Being built on a rock try to avoid going during noon as it would be hard to walk on the rock surface barefoot

Gadaladeniya is one of the 3 temples in the Embekke, Lankathilaka circuit. Closer to the Kandy-Colombo road at Pilimathalawa. Gadaladeniya is not as impressive as Lankathilaka and does not have the intricate wood carvings like Embekke. Nothing much to see as such. Pilimathalawa is known for brassware and you could do some shopping in this area. There is a ticket to visit, which is definitely not justified.
This ancient temple is located near pilimatalawa on colombo Kandy main road. Ideal for history lovers and archeology followers .

One of the three elements of the Temple Loop, the main part of this building has some serious scaffolding around it to protect the delicate roof, which makes good exterior photos very challenging.  There are some great sculptures in the entry that make up for this, and the Buddha inside is quite impressive.

We visited this 14thC temple together with the Lankatilaka and the Embekke Devale as an excursion from Kandy. The main shrine room has a large seated golden Buddha statue. There is a devalaya, dedicated to god Vishnu located next to the shrine room. The whole temple has many features of south Indian style architecture. At the time of our visit, this shrine room was covered with a temporary roof protecting the delicate paintings and artworks as well as the building but though not quite as spectacular as the Lankatilaka this is still a tranquil and spiritual place to spend some time.

The attraction of visiting this place is its age. But understand that isn't that much to see. At the same time there is hardly anybody. If you did not have a temple indigestion and it is on your way then it is worth visiting. Entry fee is 300 rupees.

We recommend a visit to this Temple which makes a contrast to the much larger Lankatilika Temple in the same region. It is accessible in a tuk tuk from Kandy town. The building complex is located on a hill top which affords very nice views. The Temple was constructed in the fourteenth century by King Wickramabahu. One can enjoy the splendid Bo tree on the Temple site, a place of dedication to gods and of course the main shrine room with the statue of the Buddha. The stonework and tiling are absolutely fascinating.

This is a very small temple and not really interesting. The setting is nice, but the temple itself is nothing special. OK, it's (very) old. Normally these kind of temples are free of charge, but they charge you 300 Rps per person without giving any information. I understand that you need some funding for maintanance, but normally this money is collected by a honesty-box (donation). So mixed feelings and only worth the visit if you don't like the crowds of Kandy and like to see something different.

Built during the early Kandy Kindom Kings, Gadaladeniya is a temple built with Stone. The temple building shows Hindu architecture, while the buddha statue is created as "Pallawa" tradition. The buddha statue had been plated with Gold, but it has been decayed. You could see glazed ceramic tiles laid inside the temple which are hundreds of year old.

One of the key places to visit while anyone passing through Kandy, but sadly the money money money is the slogan. As a Sri Lankan I get disgusted when locals and foreigners have to pay a different fee to visit these Buddhist religious places.
Interesting to go to see one of the smaller temples.  No need to worry about the crowds here - there weren't any.  The artistry is fantastic and the colours amazing.

outside kandy lies this beautiful temple. Although not as important as the temple of the tooth, this place has been once as important in the 14th century. worth the visit if you like to go far and beyond the normal tourist attractions

I would recommend visiting the three temples described here rather than any one.  Each temple has a different atmosphere and design. After a drive of about 30 minutes outside of Kandy, nestled in the hills lie three beautiful, yet different temples built in the late 1500s by King Buwanekabahu IV (1341 to 1351) and his successors. The three temples, Gadaladeniya Vihara, Sri Lankathilaka Temple and Devale, and Embekke Devale, are all within a short drive of each other ,close to the Kandy-Colombo Road, and easily accessed by 3-wheeler (tuktuk) or other vehicles.  Each temple charges 300 rupees or 3 euro/dollars and has little interpretation.  I enjoyed the ride; I don't think the walking loop would be my cup of tea. Gadaledeniya's main temple is under restoration -- and things move slowly here.  There is scaffolding, but do go inside.  This building has Indian influences since it was designed by a man from South India.  There is also a second shrine that is very unique with five image rooms each topped with a degoba in a cruciform design. Each room is unique. My driver, Lucky (077 650 8265) took me to all three temples on an excursion that lasted about 3 hours.  I paid him 10,000 rupees -- we went in a tuk tuk but he does have a car as well.

If you are tired of Kandy city and the Tooth temple then take a rickshaw up the hill and visit this temple. Very relaxed, plenty to see and not too many guests. When I was there the man who sold the tickets was also sitting outside selling his paintings. I thought they were good so i talked with him. He not only has the resposibility for the temple but he is restoring all the art. Basically a solo project. He knew everything about the temple but also could explain all about the other temples close by and the Tooth temple. Fantastic guy, I bought a few paintings which I am still happy for. Great trip

This does not get as many tourists, and hence we found the place very calm. The structure is simple, but some of the sculptures are very well done. And the Buddha statue is very impressive. But the reason that made our visit to this temple more special was the caretaker of the temple - D. Rathnayake. He clearly cares for the Buddhist temples with a passion. It reflected in the way he guided us around the temple - explaining the significance of the various sculptures. You MUST see his hand paintings of the temples. Some are postcard size, and others are A4 size paintings of various temples. We especially loved his re-creation of the Sigiriya fort - as it must have been in its full glory. He can be reached at Rathnayakearts@yahoo.com

This temple is built on solid granite rock and is worth a visit. It's not showy or flash but it is much more like a traditional Buddhist temple. The were worshippers there and the monks blessed us. Very interesting to watch the ceremony before worship. The guide is also an amazing painter and you can buy his paintings of the temple from him.
located out of the city cetere and 20 kms away from kandy. this place is within the lush greener and villages which in iotself was a great attraction.
this beautiful temple again near lankatilka, is buil on a rock and beautiful stone carvimngs are also evident within. the vegetation and rural scenery is not to be missed.
Outside is a stupa and there are four shrines. with many wall paintings.  At the time of our visit, the roof was being restored because it leaked so much.

this temple is in a very quiet location about 15km from kandy town. another great temple in this budhist country. although not that know and touristic it has a history of significant importance as it was also the main temnple like the temple of the tooth durimnh the 14th centrury. Built on a rock with beautiful carvings i relay enjoyed this place as there were not many people. entrace fees are about rs 200.

The Gadaladeniya Viharaya is the final hop on the Embekka-Lankathilaka-gadaladeniya troika of old temples around kandy. The temple is currently under renovation at the time of our visit, But still retains the old and quiet charm of a countryside temple. The locals pray by carrying a pot of water and walk around the holy tree a certain no of times and offer the water at the base of the tree as a manner of prayer to the buddha. The entrance fee to this place is 200SLR.

column7: East Riding of Yorkshire, United Kingdom
column11: Enjoyed our visit to this little temple up in the hills outside Kandy, well worth the trip. Nice little village too. Watch the woodcarver at work, we wished we had room for some of his work in our luggage.

This forms part of the Three Temples tour and is notable for bring constructed of carved stone. Relatively small one of the stupas has four side chapels which contain images of Buddha and wall paintings. The main temple has a large image. There is also a bodi tree.
I thought this temple was not particularly interesting. The guide tried hard to sell us his paintings.

This is a place to visit if you are passing by to Kandy which is located at Pilimathalawa closer to Kandy. A temple built by King Wickremabahu which needs a lot of attention and maintenance in the present.

Its worth visiting this place too if you are keen about Sri Lankas culture and especially architecture of the ancient period. How ever this place cannot be compared to Temple of the tooth relic. So if you dont have much time need to decide.

We visited here in Feb and were the only visitors around. The place is still under repair (see previous visitor photos on here from 2009!) and clearly will be a work in progress for some time to come. The entire place is built on top of a single rock and to one side there is a very large and long inscription of a letter the then king wrote. At the back of the complex there is a small natural rock pool filled with lotus flowers that is in the shape of Sri Lanka. Entrance fee was RS200 each and well worth the money.

We loved the place as it is on one of the hills .The paintings inside the prey room were made of natural colour and must have been beautiful but now you will only see remains. I liked the small Naturally made pond with lilies in mid of temple. The stone carvings on temple wall are gorgeous . If you are in Kandy, you can see this 14th century ancient temple. The entry fee is 400 lankan rupee for 2 people.

Gadaladeniya temple is located off Pilimatalawa which is about 8 to 12 milse away from the city of Kandy. If you are travelling from Colombo to Kandy, approximately 25 minutes before reaching Kandy city you have to turn right and travel for about 8 to 10 km to reach Gadaladeniya temple. This temple had been built by the Kandyan kings during the period between 16th to 17 th century where the construction, architecture and the artifacts are worthwhile watching. The temple itself is a respected place of worship for Buddhists in Srilanka.
Like Embekke this is a must see place, An ancient temple, plenty of handicraft artisans, cool weather, and a an insight  as to how artifacts may have been turned out in the eras gone by!
This is an ancient temple but is small and nondescript.  If you are spending days in Kandy, check it out.  However, if time is limited, you won't miss much by skipping it.

Excellent Temple and the Elephant added another level to this ancient place.  If you want to have your picture taken with the elephant, the handler will change you, but a fun shot with a friendly elephant.  Very old artifacts and a wondrful senior Monk!
Very impressive and must see the temple. The best time to visit is at night. We reached there about 7pm after the Kandy performance finished.
This temple dates fron 14th century and its still standing, and thats enough reason to pay a visit.

At first glimpse, it might seem that there is not much to see at this place. But history is literally carved in stone here. Don't shy away from the old gentlemen who, for a small tip, will gladly point out easy to miss details. We visited Gadaladenia as a part of the three temple loop, easily done in a morning if you have your own transportation. We loved being out on the small country roads, passing through villages and being away from the crowds inside Kandy.

now this place is far off from the city and not that well maintained..they are only particular about collecting the entry fees, after that you are upto your own...visit only if you have ample time and really interested in seeing it
these three temples has a lot to see..you can do all three temples in one go.

Gadaladeniaya Temple was build by king Wickramabahu in 1344 during the Gampola Kingdom time. Its located on a small hilltop but easily reachable by car. Another one of the temples with less tourist so its really quiet and nice to walk around, The monk there was also very friendly and told us about the history of the temple. Do take time to view the 2 pillars as one was built/carved by the master and the other by his student. Each pillar is different and unique.

It is characterized by a brick structure on an octagonal base with a moonstone at the entrance, lacquered door and numerous carvings and frescoes. You have to turn from Pilimatalawa on A1 (Colombo - Kandy road) to reach this place.. Recommend for watch. Please try to wearing long trousers. (short ,trousers and short skirts not allowed)
